Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This course required a lot of conceptual thinking and takes time to understand.
More about how physics works.
Mostly review of E/M at the AP level, with some exceptions like RLC circuits and inductance, a more rigorous treatment of Maxwell's equations, some optics, and basic QM
Electromagnetism and quantum!
I learned about Electricity and Magnetism, Optics, and Quantum Mechanics.
This class taught me the concepts behind electricity, magnetism and quantum mechanics. It also served to improve my critical thinking and problem solving skills

I took Physics C E&M in high school, but I have to say this course still offered a substantial amount of new material/intuition. The quantum mechanics unit at the end is super cool, and Demers is great at explaining those difficult ideas.
I learned a whole new branch of physics that I have never learned, so that was pretty cool. I also met really cool people who struggled through the class with me.
Problem solving
Electricity, magnetism, quantum mechanics, circuits, lenses and optics
N/A

I learned what was advertised--the fundamentals of physics spanning E+M to quantum. A fairly standard selection of topics and problems, a solid and helpful foundation for future physics or STEM studies--or just to understand the world better!
Good knowledge of electromagnetism and some quantum
I understood the nature of electricity and magnetism further.
E/M, Quantum, Circuits
A lot of the material I had never seen before, or only engaged with at very basic levels, so this course has really acted as my foundation for E&M.
Learned some about electricity and magnetism and the calculus behind it
I developed my ability to solve a wide breadth of physics problems.
Physics

I learned how to connect physical insights with mathematical equations. We had to take equations we knew, like Gauss' law for example, but know what they meant physically and how to apply them. This course covered Electricity, Magnetism and Quantum Mechanics. I had never learned Quantum Mechanics before so that was really cool.
This course improved my physics and math skills as expected and was the perfect continuation pf PHYS 200.
I learned about electromagnetism, which was integral to this semester.
Basically AP Physics C plus quantum mechanics. Don't expect to come out of this class with a great conceptual grasp of either if you haven't studied them before.
foundation in physics knowledge
I feel very comfortable with E&M basics, which is how the course was advertised. I think the quantum stuff was not quite in depth enough for me to feel like I had learned it.
My understanding of physics concepts, especially in the area of electromagnetism and Maxwells equations, has greatly improved.
I learned all about Electricity and Magnetism, with an additional emphasis on quantum and wave mechanics, as expected from a class billed as such.
Learned electricity, magnetism, quantum, and optics. I learned how to solve complex problems by combining lots of information.
I learned the basics of electricity and magnetism, optics, and quantum mechanics.
I learned a great deal about electricity and magnetism, while developing some problem solving skills
Lots of physics goodness! And some new math concepts. Doing psets  on time. Collaborative work.
I learned to apply lots of calculus principles and properties to solve physics problems that were challenging but individually interesting in their own ways.
I learned a lot more about the detailed equations behind electricity and magnetism and quantum physics.
This course generally follows professor Shankar's lectures on Youtube, which served as a good review for the course material.

Strengths: great, engaging prof; relatively interesting, necessary material for any physics major
Weaknesses: fast-paced, definitely easy to get lost without prior experience in physics and at least with a solid understanding of E/M from a college-level or AP course beforehand; questions were sometimes never really answered
Sarah is a good lecturer, although the material could be dry at times, but that's expected for intro physics
This course is very difficult and a lot of the learning falls onto the students to do by themselves. Problem sets are also very difficult and hard to do without help from TA's.

The material is really interesting and Professor Demers is a great lecturer! There was not a lot of feedback in the class though and for assessments it is hard to see what the right answers were for questions we got wrong because there are no answer keys for the quizzes and thus its hard to learn from our mistakes.

Strengths: very good overview of basic E&M
Weaknesses: N/A
There was no feedback given and it was very hard to find practice materials for tests. However, the textbook was followed very closely, but the textbook seemed long and had no good practice problems.
Teaching not easily understood

Strengths: Material is very interesting, and goes into sufficient detail and complexity. The addition of quantum mechanics makes it even more engaging
Weaknesses: The textbook (Fundamentals of Physics II by R. Shankar) is really bad and not easy to use when studying for exams and tests.

Strength: professor was nice

Weakness: Kind of disorganized and super dependent on the book

The course is well-organized and there are a lot of resources to help students succeed--from a wide range of professor and TA office hours, study halls to work on psets with peers, a decent textbook, and an available instructor. The material is interesting, but more challenging than the first semester of fundamentals, and lectures were sometimes a bit disappointing in the treatment of the complex topics of E+M. I would have liked to go more in-depth in our understanding of the math of Maxwell's equations and how it connects to physical reality, understanding the line between what we observe empirically and what we think is the explanation for those observations.
Great teacher

I thought this was a great course - as an engineering student, I learned a lot and felt very engaged with the material. I was so happy I took this over 180/181 because the psets were intellectually challenging, as were the tests, without being intimidating. I liked working on psets with students in the class, and I learned so much through that. I felt as though the first test was unnecessarily harsh in its grading, but I understand that grade stratification has to happen somewhere. Sarah is a great teacher and I was able to learn well from my notes; I rarely used the textbook. However, I felt as though students would ask useless and distracting questions in class, and Sarah was too nice and answered all of them, but it really disrupted the flow of the lecture. Overall, wonderful time!
The difficulty of the quizzes are quite variable, One was too hard, one too easy.  The lectures could be more engaging. The professor is nice
I think that the strength is in the number of TAs and peer tutors. I think it goes over excessive amounts of material
Classes arent geared toward the psets, which in turn makes them difficult

I loved Sarah. She is a great lecturer. I was always very engaged in class time, and that was the most interesting part for me. Also, I think a strength of the class was that the exams were always the right difficulty-- I could show what I knew but they were never too hard. A weakness was that I felt like the problem sets were sometimes boring compared to the lectures in class, and I was not always that excited to do them. I am not a physics major though, so maybe that is why.

The only weakness of the course was the difficulty balance of the exams. The final was significantly harder than the second midterm, which happened only a few weeks before the final. Some of felt that therefore did not devote enough time to preparing for the final.
I liked how this course had study groups where I could finish and ask questions on homework. It would have been nice if there were even smaller review sessions in addition to lecture classes.

I think that, because our professor was so nice, many people assumed that she was a great teacher, and blamed themselves when they didn't understand the material. I was lucky enough to have taken AP Physics C in high school, and the contrast between my high school teacher's and Professor Demers' teaching ability was unfortunately very stark. Professor Demers rarely did anything but derivations of the equations already derived for us in the book. So yes, we learned to use equations like bean-counting monkeys, but this approach was incredibly unhelpful to our conceptual understanding of the deep reasons why the world is the way it is, which is supposed to be what you learn in physics, isn't it? Honestly, I think a lot of the problems in this class would be solved if the professor used a different textbook. Shankar's book is one of the most useless pieces of garbage I have ever had the misfortune of coming across. It is literally 100+ pages of straight algebraic derivations. Very little conceptualizing and no examples or applications. What the fuck!

I will say, however, that the study hall system was very helpful. Working through psets during study halls were when I actually learned the material. I still would rather learn in lecture and use the homework to apply my knowledge, but as it was I found a collaborative homework space to be absolutely essential to get through the course.
shes a decent lecturer and the material is organized fairly well but shes not very organized
I thought, for what it was, it was taught fine. I wish it was a little more advanced, like a little more in the middle ground between 181 and 261.
Strengths: the study halls are super helpful, the lectures are good, the psets are a good length, the exams are very fair

This class is pretty much as effective as possible for its purpose. Its main strength is its professor, who clearly cares a lot about teaching the subject well. Feedback is good throughout the semester. Perhaps the class could have moved a little bit faster in the beginning of the semester since it is billed as a class for students that have already taken physics, but this fixed itself later in the semester when newer material was introduced.

The lectures are slow because students interrupted a lot, so it always seemed like we didn't cover enough information. The problem sets were posted very late. Having lecture notes posted online or having a Piazza page would be very helpful.
Sarah is great but her lectures are not always the most engaging. It would be cool to have more demonstrations in class and if she was a bit more organized.
It provided a good overview of various physics topics. It got a little confusing and disorganized at the end, but it was taught very well.
I felt that the textbook was rather meandering, and I'd appreciate a more straightforward text
It's taught super well, paced well, content's great.

Strengths: Good level of challenge, none of the work is excessive or busywork you can tell that every problem is picked specifically to help ground a concept in a new or interesting way, lots of support from the professor and TFs through office hours and 3 weekly study halls, clear and straightforward explanations in class Prof. Demers is never hesitant to take a pause to answer any questions students may have and yet she somehow still manages to finish the most important parts of lecture in a way that's digestible and she's also a very enthusiastic lecturer! The class is set up to encourage collaboration and camaraderie between students as well, which is really nice especially when the course content gets difficult.
Weaknesses: Long lecture times (especially in combination with heavy algebra and calculations) make the class hard to sit through sometimes but that's mostly an issue with my own attention span which is embarrassingly short for someone of my age and schooling.
Professor Demers, though very enthusiastic, sometimes does not explain the concepts very well, and moves through equations rather fast. As such, sometimes it is not as engaging as it should be.
I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in physics and eager to learn about very interesting and complicated topics.

Definitely not for non-majors who have no solid foundation in physics at the AP level (and have that material very solidly), would recommend to those who are interested in brushing up on E/M and learn a little bit more with some calculus derivations and some quantum mechanics too
Yes, relatively easy and psets were very manageable
Not necessarily, unless they were really interested in quantum mechanics and optics. It is very hard course intellectually and is only manageable if you find a good group of people to study with.
Yes! It is super interesting and rewarding!
Yeah it's great
Yeah, but only because I really like physics. Maybe a different level physics course?
Yes, helps you to think around problems
Yeah! If you are interested in physics this is a great course and you really learn a bunch. The study halls are great and you make really good friends working together in the class.

Take this course over PHYS 181 if you're interested in quantum mechanics. The content is pretty much the same, but taught at a faster pace to accommodate for 2 weeks of quantum mechanics at the end. 
The textbook - Fundamentals of Physics II by R. Shankar - is pretty bad when it comes to actually using it to study for the test. It is humorous and interesting to read, but it's supposed to be a textbook, not a novel. Shankar digresses everywhere and sometimes presents disorienting and distracting analogies in the name of humor. Even stuff that is explained is done so in a roundabout way. 
For the quantum mechanics part of the course, we were given a handout from "University Physics with Modern Physics" by Wolfgang Bauer and Gary D. Westfall. This book was very clear and explained everything in an easy to follow manner. Would recommend using this alongside the course for the entire course.

I think 200/201 was a good middle-ground intro physics course. It's impossible to accurately compare to 180/181 and 260/261 without having taking them,  but I felt like at least I knew that I would have lots of support in this class--I could always get help with psets, always ask questions after class, always watch Shankar lectures if I didn't understand material. And the groups of students was fun and eager, not as large of a class as 181, and not as difficult as 261.
Yes, Professor Demers is great and at least for me the class was good as well
Yes, I would recommend it. I found the study halls to be incredibly useful with regard to access to other students and the TAs.

Yes. Take this course if you need introductory physics; it comes with none of the stress of 180/181 and is much more conceptually sound than 260/261. This class is perfect for engineers and Sarah explains all of the concepts in-depth. Psets are handleable as well as conceptually challenging. Make sure to go to study hall if you're going to take this course; it helps a lot, and the TA's were wonderful (especially Emma!)
I would recommend this course to other students if required for their major.
I had to take it for Navy, I think Id recommend this over 181 if they have a good background in math
If interested in physics, this is a tough but thorough introduction.

If you are interested in physics, yes I would recommend it. I took this class knowing that I probably would not go on to major in physics, and I still really liked it just for being interesting. The lectures are awesome and you will learn a lot about the physical world and quantum mechanics. I think students should be prepared for the workload, though. I never felt like it was enormous, but sometimes the psets just took a little longer than I would have wanted.
Yes. This course was a great introductory physics class with a online video lecture series by Shankar to supplement it.
I would recommend this course. I learned a lot about the fundamentals of physics and the importance of electricity and magnetism.
yes if you need to take an intro physics
If you've taken a decent HS physics course, and want to continue, this course may or may not be the best course for you. I'd taken AP Physics C E&M, and found I didn't learn all that much.

Yes, I really enjoyed learning about electricity and magnetism. I didnt know what to expect because E+M was difficult in high school, but the professor did a really good job of explaining how things worked

I would recommend this course to anyone who is looking to take further classes in physics. The 260/261 courses are very difficult and open up the same optioms for future courses, so they are not worth the extra work unless you are very well prepared.

Yes, definitely. The perfect person to take this class is one who has taken AP Physics C (or other previous E+M courses), needs physics for a requirement, is worried that 181 will be too simple/tedious, and worries that 261 will be too much work/too difficult/too theoretical. This class is far less work and gives you way more bang for your buck.
This is a great intro physics course. Not too hard, not too easy. If interested at all in physics with a moderate to small background in physics, I would take this course.
I would. It was a solid introduction to higher-level physics courses.
Yes with Sarah Demers!
Yes! I learned a lot without feeling overburdened by the work in this class. I also felt very supported and welcomed into this class even without having taken the first term of the sequence.
If you are up for an intuitive and generally challenging semester of physics, I would recommend this course! For more basic/introduction physics, take 181.
If you get Professor Demers, this is a great intro physics course for people with a multivariable calc background who are nervous about physics. I have heard other professors are more proof-focused.
